Instrument_PDS3.instrument_desc:
Instrument Overview ===================
The High-Speed Occultation Timing Photometer is operated by the University of Maryland (UMD). The system consists of a portable Celestron C-14 Schmidt-Cassegrain telescope, a photometry package (optics, selectable apertures, eyepiece, and detector), and an electronics package for operating the system and recording data.
Optics ======
The following optical parameters can be found at manufacturer's (Company 7) web site, http://www.company7.com/celectron/products:
Design : Schmidt-Cassegrain Catadioptric Effective Aperture : 14 inches, 355.6 millimeters Nominal Focal Length : 154 inches, 3910 millimeters Nominal Focal Ratio : f/11 Primary Mirror : 14.25-inch diameter, f/2.14, spherical Secondary Mirror : 3.5-inch diameter, spherical Central Obstruction : 4.5 inches overall Optical Tube : 30 inches long, 16-inch diameter Back Focus : 14 inches from apex of primary mirror Optimum back focus : Approximately 4 inches Finder scope : 5-inch diameter
For observations with the photomultiplier detector, any one of four apertures is inserted into the focal plane of the telescope, to select a field of view of 30 arcseconds. The aperture is positioned over the target of interest, and all light passing through is recorded by the photomultiplier tube and electronics as a function of time.
Detector ========
The detector is an EMI 9892B/350 bi-alkali, borosilicate photomultiplier tube with end-on illumination. For observations made without filters, the responsivity is determined mainly by the combination of the photocathode response with the borosilicate transmission curve: peak response occurs near 375 nm and half-quantum-efficiency points occur near 310 nm and 520 nm. The resultant bandpass of the telescope and photometer system ranges from 312 to 615 nanometers with an effective wavelength of 453 nanometers.
Electronics ===========
The electronics package first converts signal (from the target) and reference currents to voltages, then to audio signals using a voltage-to-frequency converter. The electronics combine the audio signal with an audio timing broadcast and voice comments, then record these data on a four-track audiotape recorder.
The audio timing track is typically time and frequency information broadcast by the WWV radio station operated by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST). Information about WWV is available at the NIST Time and Frequency web site:
http://tf.nist.gov/timefreq/index.html
During data collection, the observers record the UTC time associated with selected WWV seconds ticks. Later, the four-track audiotapes are digitized, and the recorded UTC times are used to synchronize the data. The resulting digitized data are considered to be raw.
Before the D/Shoemaker-Levy 9 impact expedition to Mt. Singleton, the UMD high-speed digital electronics were inoperable. A similar occultation timing system with the same high-speed analog electronics was borrowed from Lowell Observatory and used on this expedition.
Measured Parameters ===================
For the D/Shoemaker-Levy 9 expedition to Mt. Singleton, the goal was to measure the light curves of Io and Europa during the impacts of several fragments of the comet with Jupiter. The following data were recorded directly onto a four-track audiotape:
1. Data counts produced the photometer, recorded as a frequency 2. WWV time signals 3. A 60Hz reference signal 4. Voice comments of the observers
Operational Considerations ==========================
To perform tracking, the target should first be centered in the field of view. Then, an observer looks through the five-inch finder scope attached to the telescope and uses a hand paddle to guide on the target. Wind may interfere with tracking if the system is unprotected.
